title: 106_hr2577
content: The Act may be cited as the "Jackson Multi-Agency Campus Act of 1999". The "Jackson Multi-Agency Campus Act of 1999" aims to consolidate administrative offices of various agencies and entities in Jackson, Wyoming to improve communication and reduce costs. The Act aims to consolidate agencies in Jackson, Wyoming to improve communication, reduce costs, and better serve the public. It authorizes federal agencies to develop and maintain the Project, provide resources, and convey federally owned land to the town of Jackson in exchange for construction of facilities for the Bridger-Teton National Forest. The Act directs the Secretary to convey federally owned land to the town of Jackson, Wyoming, for the construction of facilities for the Bridger-Teton National Forest. It also involves conveying land to the Game and Fish Commission of Wyoming in exchange for land to be used in the Project's construction, and relinquishing reversionary interests of the United States to facilitate these transactions. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Commission" refers to the Game and Fish Commission of Wyoming. "Construction cost" means costs associated with building improvements to Federal standards through a competitive bidding process. The term "Federal parcel" refers to a 15.3-acre land parcel on the Bridger-Teton National Forest. The "Map" is a document dated March 31, 1999, depicting the Multi-Agency Campus Project Site. The "master plan" is a document dated July 14, 1998, outlining the conceptual plan. The term "master plan" refers to the Conceptual Master Plan document dated July 14, 1998, for a proposed multi-agency campus project in Jackson, Wyoming, providing facilities for agencies, entities, and visitors in the greater Yellowstone area. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The term "State parcel" refers to a specific land parcel. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture, including a designee. The term "State parcel" refers to a 3-acre land parcel depicted as "Wyoming Game and Fish" on the Map. The term "town" refers to Jackson, Wyoming. SEC. 4. MULTI-AGENCY CAMPUS PROJECT, JACKSON, WYOMING. The town may offer to construct an administrative facility for the Bridger-Teton National Forest in exchange for Federal land. The Commission may offer to convey a portion of the State parcel for the same purpose. The Secretary will convey Federal land to the Commission in exchange for a portion of the State parcel if the offer is made within 5 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will convey Federal land to the town and the Commission in exchange for specified portions of the Federal parcel. The United States will also relinquish reversionary interests in the State parcel as part of the exchange. The fair market and improvement values of the land to be exchanged under this Act shall be determined by appraisals acceptable to the Secretary, in accordance with federal standards. Each appraisal report must adhere to Federal standards and not consider any reversionary interests held by the United States in the State parcel. The Secretary will adjust the acreage of Federal land conveyed to the town based on whether its value is greater or less than the construction costs for the administrative facility. Additional Federal land may be conveyed if needed to match the construction costs closely. The Secretary will adjust the acreage of Federal land conveyed to the town to match the construction costs for the administrative facility. The value of Federal land must be equal to the State parcel conveyed, and boundaries can be adjusted for equalization. Cash payments can be made if values cannot be equalized by adjusting parcel sizes or conveying additional land without compromising the Project's design. SEC. 7. ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS. Construction of facilities on Federal land within the Project boundaries shall be supervised and managed by the town to approved standards. The town, including contractors, shall have access to the land for construction purposes. Land acquired by the United States under this Act will be governed by national forest site laws. No construction is allowed in wetland areas after the land conveyance date. Deeds and conveyance documents will include necessary reservations. Deeds and conveyance documents executed by the Secretary under this Act must include reservations to prevent wetland development on Federal parcels.
